Fields.DialogueText: Have you seen my bowl, Kapitan?
The wooden bowl you just made?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I've seen it. It's in the galley, where it belongs.
No, I haven't seen it.
You should keep better track of your belongings.

Fields.DialogueText: Gah! That was the first place I looked. I hope someone didn't misplace it. I hope I didn't!
Hmmm... it couldn't have gotten very far. If it were only alive I could sense it...
I know where I put it, but it wasn't there when I went for it. I'm almost certain of that.
What do you need the bowl for, anyway? It seems more like a decorative item than a functional bowl.
I made ukha! Fish soup, freshly caught in the ocean and boiled in the waters of Baikal.
It is! But I use it when I feel I need to be close to my home, such as if there is a great challenge ahead.
Oh! Here it is! Someone was using it to store cigarettes.
Not the most respectful of uses.
Which is fine. The Buryat love to bet any chance they get. It is how Khutulun amassed a pasture of thousands of horses. I wonder what luck passed through this bowl...
*ALARM*
If finding it was the challenge you mentioned, that would have been pretty lucky.
We'll catch it as it comes, Kapitan! Like a nerpa and its prey...
@BATTLE
Da, that's the one. I feel like I only just put it down...
I thought that Baikal water was precious to you.
Like a missing bowl?
Let's hope that's all we have to look forward to. The spirits and the Lord were both vague on that.
It was near a deck of cards, so I gather it was used for gambling.

Fields.MenuText: I wish I could tell the difference between Baikal water and normal water.
You're not running out, are you?
Shame we didn't find those leaks earlier.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not something you taste, Kapitan... it's something you feel. Though when you've been in as many waters as I have, certain things start to stand out.
I've still got a stack of them. Once my ukha cravings pass, the supply should last for the foreseeable future.
We didn't lose much, Kapitan. Besides, the decks needed some cleansing.
What are you going to do once you run out? It's not like you can go up the Yenisey to get more.
Shouldn't be difficult. Uncle Joe sends plenty of friends out east to help!
*ALARM*
Ah, right on time. Another fishing advantage: when the haul gets worse, Rusalki are likely near.
I doubt you'd want to eat any fish that stuck around.
Not without some serious boiling. I've heard awful rumors about dolphins that strayed too close...
@BATTLE
Say, Kapitan, care for some freshly made ukha?
I don't know if I could eat another bite - we've been having a lot of it lately. It's good, mind you.
More for me, then. It looks like I'll have to crack another Baikal barrel.
... You mean Stalin.
Who did you think I meant? Goebbels?
Why is there water all over the table?
I'm afraid to ask.
The crew aren't. They're just annoyed that I'm taking up space with my project.
Here, please clean it up.
Nyet! Don't touch it, Kapitan!
Why not?

Fields.MenuText: I thought you enjoyed cleaning?
What are ice emeralds?
Don't be so bashful. It's just water.

Fields.DialogueText: I like working with my hands, but who truly enjoys cleaning? The result, sure, but the process... eh.
When Lake Baikal freezes, the ice turns a brilliant hue of green. Ice emeralds!
Zamechatel'no! Let it vanish and leave its mark on the world.
*ALARM*
Don't move that water, Kapitan! It is sacred water from the oldest lake in the world. Even if it leaves a stain on the table, that is considered a blessing.
I guess I have no say in this.
I'll let this one slide. But one word about any messes being a blessing from old Russian ships and we're sticking you in dry dock.
Oh, Kapitan! Who would I invoke? Petr Veliky? I'm traditional, not reactionary.
@BATTLE
Hear me out. I tried making ice emerald earrings. But... the ice emeralds melted.
The experiment was a failure, I fear.
It's not that bad. I could just take my sleeve and-
Not really, nyet.
I don't like waiting around like this.
There's not some fishing lure you could be making?
That's when I'm not waiting for anything in particular. I'm expecting more wood from the dealer in Leningrad.
I'm a small vessel with a small complement. I can afford to make enough for everyone.

Fields.MenuText: What did you trade this time? More narwhal tusks?
How does the Red Fleet feel about indulging this?
You could always collect more narwhal tusks while you wait.

Fields.DialogueText: Cold, hard rubles this time. I don't do a whole lot else with my pay.
The same way the Kremlin feels about Stalin's dachas, I expect. Disapproving, but only mildly.
Tempting, but I don't hunt only for the sport of it. That's a good way to empty the seas around me!
And before you ask - nyet, it's not going to be a whole trunk this time. I had him cut it into pieces.
That's a relief. It's cramped enough here as it is.
*ALARM*
You might be one of the only Belles to promise that. I'm trying to commit this moment to memory.
Ha! Don't believe everything you hear about us. Especially not those bits.
@BATTLE
Whenever the wood decides to arrive, of course. The anticipation is killing me!
Just in case the bowl goes missing again?
I've learned my lesson, Kapitan. I won't inconvenience the sailors for the sake of one of my projects.
Is something wrong, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: Nerpa, if this is another one of those crazy Belle projects...
This could be dangerous. I want this thing overboard.
You weren't expecting something living, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Honest, Kapitan, I thought I knew what I was getting into too!
Not until we know what it is, Kapitan! Whatever it is, I guarantee you I can deal with it.
Of course not! Well, not in the physical sense.
Just one moment while I knife this open... there!
Bozhe moy! Kapitan, look at this poor thing!
Not just any seal pup! It's a Baikal seal! My namesake!
*ALARM*
Nerpa, is this really the time?
It's the only time. I'll be there soon!
@BATTLE
I'm not really sure. I was expecting more than one box from the dealer.
What's in the crate, Nerpa?
*KNOCK*
Also, not airholes.
Wet straw? Great. More water to leak all over the-
A seal pup?
What's a seal doing here? You didn't order one.
Never mind that, Kapitan. Get the crew to their stations - I'm making sure this little kheruvim is safe and warm.
Care for a taste, Kapitan?
Aghk! You couldn't have led with that?
Hmm... It could stand a little more cod liver oil.
Usually not. Fermented mare's milk is more common. Much saltier, too. You'll have to try it one day.
The warrior or the seal?
Well, some of them wagered ten or a hundred. There were many nonetheless. But she also knew when to make sacrifices for peace.
Some histories say she married an assassin sent by her cousin Kublai Khan to kill her father, Kaidu.

It's a whole lot of back and forth. The assassin's mother offered her life in his place after he was caught. Then he insisted that no, he should be the one executed. His family loyalty rated a pardon.
Whether it was a marriage for peace or some other reason, she retired undefeated. Her choice.

Fields.MenuText: Strange thing, marrying someone who tried to kill your father.

Fields.DialogueText: And that brings us to our seal. Khutulun knew when to fight and when not to. She knew lives were to be preserved, not spent. Why not preserve this one?
Assuming the milk doesn't kill it first.
*ALARM*
Oh, really, Kapitan! Try it from the source and tell me this is so bad.
@BATTLE
Politics.
Hmm. Tastes odd. Some kind of soup?
Nyet. This is the latest batch of imitation seal milk.
Do people actually drink this stuff where you're... "from?"
Well, if it's good enough for Khutulun...
You really look up to her, don't you?
She isn't worshipped like Temüjin - Genghis Khan - but I think she would have wanted it this way. Her deeds spoke for themselves.
Ten thousand horses from ten thousand suitors, right?
Hell of a courtship.

Fields.MenuText: Did she wrestle after that?
Marriage or war doesn't seem like much of a choice.

Fields.DialogueText: Undoubtedly! It takes more than marriage to quell the thirst for battle.
She believed it was the best way to preserve the khanate and her people. Who's to say she was wrong?

Fields.MenuText: Catching narwhals?
It's so intricate. I didn't know you could weave so finely.
What's the hunt?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe one at a time. No, I'm thinking smaller.
I'm getting carried away, to be honest. Any bigger and we might be able to catch one of my sisters!
Fish. Lots and lots of it.
The seal still has plenty of time to live on milk, doesn't it?
I'm thinking ahead, Kapitan. A seal like this one eats lots and lots of fish, and you don't find its favorites outside of the lake.
Idyot on gustoyu taigoyu, gde ptashki odni lish poyut...
Lots and lots of ocean fish should be the next best thing.
It's a colorful net. Lots of blues  and grays, kind of like... wait a minute.
Don't we have a generous crew, Kapitan?
*ALARM*
I always have time! This will keep me working for the whole tour. And it's all thanks to little Khutulun there...
@BATTLE
That's one way to keep the seal warm.
If I can't make a den for it, my body heat is the next best thing. Oh, for a samovar to heat water in...
Better stock up on narwhal tusks.
You laugh, but when capitalism breathes its last I will be ready with my barter.
Speaking of which... like my net?
You stole their uniforms to make a fishing net?
They volunteered. I put in an order for more fabric in the meantime.
Walk with me. You're not seriously going to make new uniforms for them? Do you even have the time?
She, Kapitan. Show a little respect!
It's got a name already?
Something smells fishy in here, don't you think?
I'll say. That net of yours worked wonders in its test run.
We can't keep quite so many for too long, so it looks like the crew are eating lots of fish in the days to come.

Fields.MenuText: So there's potatoes to peel and now fish to clean. Wonderful.
What are we going to do with all of it that doesn't get eaten?
How long until our new friend can help?

Fields.DialogueText: Just one more thing to keep my hands busy. But you're welcome to assist whenever you'd like!
Chum for narwhals?
It takes a couple of months to get them onto solid food. Won't be long now.
If you don't mind smelling like fish for the foreseeable future, I guess this works out.
No worse than smelling like seal. And it's worth it if we save Khutulun's life. Did I ever tell you about the real Khutulun?
In passing. You look up to her as a warrior, if I recall.
Is she telling you to pack your hold with fish?
She's telling me that it's a small sacrifice for a greater good.
Halibut it is tonight, then.
@BATTLE
On and off the battlefield. She was as compassionate as she was brave. You might say she's guiding my hand here.
*ALARM*
I'll even cook!
Look, it's grey and fluffy!
It looks pretty lethargic, don't you think?
There's an empty bottle here... It's a miracle the poor thing hasn't starved. Here, we need to make some seal milk until we can get a better substitute.
With what mother seal?
Don't need one. Seal milk is mostly fat with a fair amount of protein mixed in. Let's see...
We'll need a can of evaporated milk, water, some butter, cream, an egg, and cod liver oil. For good measure, we'll add a little sugar in there to perk him back up.
Oh! We need to warm it up first. You shouldn't nurse a baby seal unless they are warm.
What can I do?
I've got it on a rag and straw underneath that light. Just gather what you can from the galley. I'll make sure it's warm.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: Is this pup going to make it?
Why does it need to be warm to eat?
I wasn't talking about the seal. We're under attack.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure how long it's been stuck in here. We'll give it a fighting chance.
Blubber. If they have to waste energy on keeping warm, they'll never survive in the cold Baikal waters.
I sensed it before the alarm went off. I'll save every life aboard me, Kapitan, human and otherwise.
Don't worry about the seal. It needs time to warm up before we can feed it.
You know what you're doing. I'll see you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
Nerpa...
I found that rubber tube you were looking for.

Fields.MenuText: How do you tube feed?
I'm familiar with the process. I'm surprised Khutulun was able to live on the bottle she shipped with.
This looks invasive.

Fields.DialogueText: Just watch, Kapitan, and maybe hold the seal. I'll demonstrate how it's done. I should have gotten you in on this earlier.
Miracles do happen. Now, watch. This isn't so different from any farm animal.
It's not as bad as it looks. Here, let me show you. This way you can do it, should you need to.
First we measure how long the tube needs to be. We measure on the side of the pup, from mouth to stomach area.
Now we warm the rubber tube in hot water. Get the seal to swallow it, and then we can let gravity do its work through a funnel.
Definitely not. I still haven't figured out where the mixup happened. But the seal's our responsibility now.
I've been teaching them too. What a lucky little kheruvim, to have forty parents!
It'll need to learn to swim eventually.
Not in the ocean, of course. Salt water's not good for her.
*ALARM*
Maybe I can flood a compartment with Baikal water...
@BATTLE
Spasibo! I thought I'd lost it. I've been tube-feeding Khutulun, even if the formula might not taste as good as the real thing.
I can vouch for that.
Quiet, you. It's best to tube feed before they nurse from a bottle if they are weakened like this.
Did you ever expect to be doing this?
The crew certainly seem to be taking to her.
We are not doubling up crew quarters for your seal.
Just a thought, Kapitan. Now let's keep these Rusalki from flooding us!

Fields.MenuText: What happened to preserving life?
Don't get me wrong. I could get used to it.
I don't think I can feel anything below my waist...

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I didn't freeze them. That's on Kappel and Kolchak above him.
Even we Buryats may freeze if we don't bundle up. Granted, I'm the only Buryat that runs on diesel.
Waist not, want not. Get it?
We're so far north that almost everywhere I look is south.
Where else will we get reindeer milk?
Is that really going to work?
The people up here drink it, so it's easier to get. And the fat content's comparable to seal milk. That's what we're really after.
That had crossed my mind. I will have to trade my bowl to get the milk.
Isn't that really precious to you?
I've made one before. I can always make another.
@BATTLE
The cold is invigorating, don't you think?
*ALARM*
It's invigorating my survival instincts.
Oh, this is nothing compared to the Great Siberian Ice March. Some say Kappel's frozen men are still at the bottom of a mile of water...
Heh. White Army, indeed.
Read the room, Nerpa.
The locals don't use rubles, of course.
Any word from the wood dealer?
Not yet. Hope for the best and prepare for the worst.
All right, here's how we make the reindeer milk fit for little Khutulun.
Otlichno! You're a natural at wildlife preservation.
If only we had a bowl to feed the seal with.
Very funny, Kapitan. Perhaps you will share a cell with the inventor of paradoxes.
If Stalin can find him. I hear he's never where you look.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't sound so hard.
You're the expert. Why don't you show me?
If she has teeth, why not feed her fish?

Fields.DialogueText: Seals have sharp teeth! Remember, unlike a cow, they are predators of the lake.
You just be patient. The seal pup knows that the bottle is food.
She's still too young to eat fish. Not long now, though.
*ALARM*
All right, I'll feed her.
@BATTLE
Ha! All right, I'm laughing too hard. You hold the bottle for her.
Separate the cream, get the ratio right, and warm it up. Couldn't be simpler.
You sure?
I can hold her tighter if the ship rocks. But she will get to know you, Kapitan! One way or another.
Can you wiggle over here? Of course you can!
Looks like Khutulun's on the mend.

Fields.MenuText: Sure. Like this?
Later, I'm busy right now.
I'll just watch you do it. You're the expert.

Fields.DialogueText: No need to force it, she'll come to you... There, see? She likes it.
What are you doing? Is it something important, or something fun? I do like trying new things.
Oh, I wouldn't go that far! But it would be odd not to at least know how to take care of my namesake.
I think she needs some fresh air. Now that she's eating well enough, there's no need to keep it too warm in here.
Got enough fabric for another coat?
Until they start making it harder to move.
*ALARM*
Not all of us have boilers or blubber to keep us warm.
@BATTLE
Working on it. I think she's hungry, though. Want to feed her?
I'll rig up something for her. Just think how nice and cold I get to keep it in the submarine now!
Assuming we can find some fresh water for her.
All thanks to us, Kapitan! She'll be swimming in no time.
Think we can take her swimming outside a combat zone?
Da. I can always get more, but I think I over-ordered for the crew's spares anyway.
Better cold than hot. You can always put on another layer when it's cold.
Nor steel skin. That's what I'm here for!
Should we consider this table yours for personal projects?
It would certainly make things simpler.
Simpler for whom?
Everyone, after a fashion. The crew have already started eating in shifts.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't sound simpler.

Fields.DialogueText: Neither did submarines when humans invented them. Now look where we are!
It seems the crew are taking to seal raising pretty well.
That surprises you?
It's not exactly what they signed up for.
So are you. Even when you're taking up the mess to make a... what exactly is that, anyway?
I'm breaking up empty Baikal barrels. If I can make a pool for Khutulun to splash around in, she'll be much less cramped.
*ALARM*
And what, just tow it along behind us?
I'll keep it in port, of course. She's a mascot, not a figurehead.
Neither am I. I think it reminds them of home, in a way. Taking care of a beloved pet is something everyone can understand. And Khutulun's a friendly face.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: On their initiative, or on yours?
And taking care of Khutulun. I've seen the chore sheet.

Fields.DialogueText: One of the torpedomen came up with the idea! I didn't even have to suggest it.
Our sailors know how to make the best of a limited space! It's essential to submarine life.
V zaklyucheniye! That wood dealer got back to me.
Some glupost' or other about a visit from the NKVD. They were under the impression our dealings were a security risk.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds like more than just nonsense.
Is he still... all right?
... Are they?

Fields.DialogueText: They backed off once they verified it was me he was talking to. Me, and no one else.
Shaken, but no worse for wear. The Red Fleet's actually demanded the NKVD apologize, though how that will shake out is anyone's guess.
All Belle mail goes through the military censor first. The things they must have to read back on land... scandalous!
So what's the verdict?
I'll have my wood, Kapitan. The dealer is now on the Red Fleet's payroll.
Meaning they're watching his every move.
Someday they won't have to, Kapitan. When the state finally withers away, people will monitor themselves!
The funniest ones have a speck of truth to them. We First Comrades know to self-monitor already.
@BATTLE
What took him so long?
I can't tell if that was supposed to be a joke.
That's your story and you're sticking to it.
There's enough of an ongoing debate about us that I can afford to.
*ALARM*
Whatever collective regime the future holds, there will be bowls enough for all!
Whew... Finished. Bozhe moy, that took forever.
This isn't only a knife, you know!
What is it?
Steel, but... more. Later.

Fields.MenuText: It'll certainly hold water.

Fields.DialogueText: And a very impatient seal!
She's coming up on the end of her liquid diet. It's time to start her hunting.
That might be fun to watch. Chumming the pool?
At first, and then we'll upgrade to live fish. She needs to learn how to fend for herself.
Cutting up barrels with only a knife tends to.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Spoken like someone asked to describe Stalin.
Ha! That seems like a safe answer.
So? What do you think of the pool I made?

Fields.MenuText: Is it lashed together with the netting you made?
Is it going to be big enough for Khutulun?

Fields.DialogueText: I can always make more. But lately I've been hunting fish on my own. You should try it!
For now. By the time she gets older we'll have found somewhere more permanent.
... And she will not do that aboard a submarine.
One day at a time, Nerpa. One day at a time.
Oh, I miss her already.
That's my little Khutulun! Always the charmer.
Shame about your Baikal water, though.
At first I missed it, Kapitan. But Khutulun needs it more. Even if I cannot feel the lake's spirit, I know it is there.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure Khutulun feels the same way.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, seals are simpler creatures than that. But she will be happiest once she's finally in Baikal where she belongs.
Maybe one day she'll even find that treasure from the Ice March.
Oh, that's lost to history and time. Twenty years at the bottom of the world's deepest lake... And besides, seals can't even dive that deep.
... Do we?
What do we know about Khutulun?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Do we know where Genghis Khan was buried?
She's safe in port, Nerpa. Plenty of clean water and fish... and I hear she's a hit with the locals.

Fields.MenuText: Not to mention the space that's been freed up.
You've still got that wood coming.

Fields.DialogueText: Worry not, Kapitan. I will put it to use again.
For everyone to share in!
You're not even interested in going in search of it? A modern-day treasure hunt?
Nyet. But he's still venerated.
Even less. That just means I have to honor her memory even more!
With some Morgana wrestling.
Bozhe moy, to get my hands on one of those Rusalki...
At least in Ulan Bator.
The larger point stands - you don't need to see something to remember why it was important.
Whoa! Careful, Nerpa!
Ne volnuytes'. I'm well aware of where everyone is aboard me.
Ah! There we go. Goodness, that must weigh hundreds of kilos.

Fields.MenuText: That's still less wood than I was expecting.
How much is that in horses?
How many bowls will that make?

Fields.DialogueText: As Khutulun weaned off of milk, so I'm weaning off of Baikal things.
Depends on the horse! I don't know if Khutulun wrestled those, but the image is fun.
Enough. Whatever's left over I can scrimshaw on. Or burn.
*ALARM*
There you are. You disappeared almost as soon as the Morganas went down.
Hmm? Da, Kapitan, I suppose I did.
How's the whittling?
Inspiration struck. That's a really good Khutulun.
One advantage to having hobbies that take up space: your things stay right where you left them.
@BATTLE
Legko. I'm almost done with this one already. Ordinarily I don't scrimshaw patterns on the outside until the inside is done, but...
Promise me, Kapitan? Promise me we'll play with her now and again once the war's over?
We'll visit her. But first we've got to find her a new home.
An inland one. The coasts are not safe for her.
You'll make them safe.
We Buryats are a betting people, Kapitan. We know the value of hedging our wagers.
Almost... almost...
Nerpa, let's get going. We've got Morganas!
Doing a little thrill-seeking today?
Nerpa!
Izvineniya, Kapitan. I was caught up in my sanding when the Rusalki attacked.
Da, I'm coming! Don't capsize yourself.

Fields.MenuText: There isn't any more to it than that?

Fields.DialogueText: You miss Khutulun, don't you?
Maybe a little bit more, but it's getting better.
It's that anticipation again, Kapitan. I've sent letters all around to zoos and interior ministries. It's waiting to hear back that's needling at me.
This bowl's almost smooth. I've just got a little more-
Ther's only so much you can do in the meantime. I'm glad you're keeping busy, at least. And the bowl's something to remember Khutulun by.
For whoever I give it to.
You're not keeping it?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: See that it doesn't happen again.
Credit where it's due. That bowl is smooth as anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. I'm not normally one to cut these things so close.
And there's not even any lacquer on it yet. You know how thorough I am.
I thought I'd challenge the crew to some fishing. Biggest catch gets the bowl.
Dinner has been decidedly land-based lately. I was almost starting to miss the fish.
That, and it's... it's good for me, Kapitan.
Letting go?
Communist, remember? I'm getting better at the whole sharing thing.
Ah, nakonets! They got back to me!
The People's Commissariat of Fish Industry. Minister Ishkov was keen to hear about my conservation efforts.

Fields.MenuText: Will she be able to adapt?
That's what's best for her.
Not in a zoo somewhere?

Fields.DialogueText: With close monitoring at first. They won't just turn her loose.
I just wish I could deliver her to those waters myself.
She would be well taken care of, but it wouldn't truly be home.
At least one nerpa will make it back to Baikal, Kapitan.
And you, and everyone else who served aboard me. I do hope some of them visit her.
*ALARM*
Konechno. There are no Rusalki on land!
@BATTLE
Who's the letter from?
Don't keep me in suspense. What's he say?
He... Oh, Kapitan, this is incredible! He wants Khutulun back in Baikal where she belongs!
All thanks to you.
Baikal's pretty remote. That's a bit of a hike.
Nowhere is too far or too dangerous for family.
Nowhere?
You've been bowling up a storm.

Fields.MenuText: I mean making bowls.
You'd be a fish out of water in the alley.
A hunter like you? I disagree.

Fields.DialogueText: Just a joke, Kapitan. Not all of mine are about my country.
Or a seal out of water! Doing its best, but she knows what she likes.
I suppose a bowling ball might not be so different than an arrow. Just heavier.
At this rate, you'll be done with that Baikal wood in no time.
Neuzheli... and I hadn't really decided what to do with the shavings and waste wood.
Can't they just go overboard?
Nikogda! Kapitan, have you ever known me to leave my hunting grounds a mess?
I don't just fire arrows blindly into the steppe. What if a fish choked on a chunk of wood, thinking it was a tasty treat?
*ALARM*
Oh, we have, Kapitan. We have.
@BATTLE
Ha! I fear I wouldn't be so good at the sport.
It's a big ocean. And wood breaks down.
You're worried about being haunted by the ghost of a fish?
It's the principle of the thing, Kapitan. Spirits take notice if you offend them.
You'd think they'd have taken notice of the Morganas.
I can't help it, Kapitan. The handoff's this week.
Certainly more than whoever was shipping her around in a crate.
Do you think we'll ever find out who in the Red Fleet ordered a baby seal in the first place? And why?
I prefer not to think about that, Kapitan. Too many disturbing possibilities.
I'm more concerned with who got the wood I ordered. Curious, more like.
For those with the luxury. I'm a submarine. No room for a coffee table, no matter how it might remind me of home.
Unless you're carving bowls out of it.
Tools, Kapitan. With a use and a place that makes life simpler.
Khutulun will find her place soon.
If the Commissariat's able to get letters to you, that must mean the mixup's been resolved by now.
We are not ordering more seals.
Never, Kapitan. Their home is far, far from the front lines.
@BATTLE
You don't say. Hmm...
Focus, Nerpa.

Fields.MenuText: Khutulun will be fine. The Commissariat knows what it's doing.
Have you decided on how you're going to say goodbye?
I know. You've talked about little else.

Fields.DialogueText: Little Khutulun is precious to me. Would it not be strange if I didn't?
In Buryat and through a curtain of tears. I've got the rough outline in place.
At least it would have made a good conversation piece.
*ALARM*
Do svidaniya, Khutulun. I'm glad you're safe...
It was nice of the Commissariat to tag her for you.
It was, but...
But?

Fields.MenuText: I thought you wanted to visit her.
If you love something, let it go.
Baikal's far away from any fighting. She'll be safe there.

Fields.DialogueText: It would be nice to visit, but she's not truly mine to keep. She's a friend.
She's a seal. She should be free to do seal things.
The Japanese are still stinging from Khalkhin Gol, after all. Zhukov's already made Siberia safe.
She's a little like the real Khutulun, isn't she? A persistent fighter.
There's not a whole lot we know about that, is there?
I think... if I didn't know where she was, as long as she was in her home, that would be enough for me.
Did I ever tell you what she spent her last years doing?
Nyet, but what we do know is fascinating. When her father died, she stood watch over his tomb.
I'm guessing she didn't get to be queen, then.
She had fourteen brothers. There's only so much wrestling one can do.
But she didn't need a throne to protect those she loved.
And besides, her family's empire crumbled in the ensuing years. Maybe she had the last laugh after all.
*ALARM*
On a long enough timeline, spite tends to pay off. You just might not be around to see it.
Whatever happens to the world... however the Rusalki are dealt with... I have a feeling at least some of us will still be satisfied.
@BATTLE
Do you know what I miss most about Baikal?
Is it possible to miss somewhere you've never been?
If you've grown up hearing enough about it, I think it is. There are plenty of First Comrades who will never see their namesakes.

Fields.MenuText: It must be hard being a Belle.
Maybe they should be named after port cities from now on.
There are definitely some lucky ones, too.

Fields.DialogueText: We have all the world's oceans to travel, and yet we have less freedom than you humans. You are like organs that can roam independently of their body.
You'd eventually run out of those, wouldn't you? But the thought is nice.
New Orleans, Southampton, Emden... and most of the Japanese girls, of course. Especially the ones named after the weather.
What I've heard about the lake... what I know about it... is how impossibly clear it is.
If the lake hasn't frozen.
*ALARM*
I suppose not. But maybe it's for the best. Remember what happened the last time the military went in it? The White Army remembers...
@BATTLE
On a good winter's day you can see almost as far down as I am long.
Even then. You can walk right across it and look down into the abyss.
That sounds dizzying. It'd be like looking down from a skyscraper.
That's part of what makes it so special to the Buryats. There's nothing artificial about its majesty. It simply... is. And we get to live with it.
And Khutulun gets to live in it.
Such a lucky little kheruvim she is!
But perhaps the lake was not meant for my kind. We submarines have a whole ocean to explore. Why go stirring up a lake?
Nothing wrong with wanting to see it. Especially for someone named after a resident.
Nothing like some fresh-made ukha caught with our uniform net.
We all make sacrifices, don't we?

Fields.MenuText: Sounds a little morbid.
What kept Khutulun going?
There is such a thing as giving too much.

Fields.DialogueText: If you prefer the medical sense, I suppose it might be.
Her family or the promise of fish, depending on which you refer to.
Not if it brings you fulfillment. Sometimes the greatest joy in life is to see others thrive.
The Commissariat rewarded me for saving Khutulun, incidentally.
I received something less... transactional.
Is that-
Another barrel, Kapitan. They took notice of how glowingly I wrote of the lake.
Certainly not hoard it as I once did. Perhaps... perhaps I'll try my hand at ice emerald earrings again.
I don't know if I'd phrase it quite like that. I think... the things that keeps us going are pieces of ourselves.
Eaten out of bowls carved from wood from the bed of my lake.
I think we all got a little reward folded into our wages. For preserving a national symbol, I think the reasoning was.
Any idea what you'll do with it?
It gets pretty stuffy down here. Those are bound to melt.
Da, but they will be beautiful while they last. And when they run down my shoulders, it may be the next best thing to bathing in snowmelt.
Bathing in snowmelt, hunting with a nerpa... you're practically in Baikal already.
With treasures better than the Tsar's lost gold.
